title: 115_hr5329
content: The Act titled "Poison Center Network Enhancement Act of 2018" establishes and maintains a national toll-free number and enhanced communication capabilities for poison control centers. The Secretary provides coordination and assistance to poison control centers for the development of a nationwide toll-free phone number and enhanced communication capabilities. The Secretary may consult with professional organizations in the field of poison control. This assistance does not restrict the work of poison control centers during public health emergencies. Authorization of Appropriations: $700,000 authorized for each fiscal year from 2019 to 2023. SEC. 3. Reauthorization of nationwide public awareness campaign to promote poison control center utilization and their public health emergency response capabilities. The Secretary is required to conduct a national public awareness campaign to educate the public and healthcare providers on poisoning, toxic exposure, and drug misuse prevention. This campaign will also highlight the availability of poison control center resources and the nationwide toll-free number. Additionally, the Secretary may consult with professional organizations in the field of poison control response to determine the most effective methods for raising public awareness. The Secretary may contract with public or private entities for an awareness campaign on poisoning and toxic exposure prevention. This includes developing and distributing prevention materials, public service announcements, and other activities for public and professional education. The Secretary will also establish baseline measures and benchmarks for evaluation. The Secretary will establish baseline measures and benchmarks to evaluate the impact of the nationwide public awareness campaign. $800,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2019 to 2023 for this purpose. SEC. 4. REAUTHORIZATION OF THE POISON CONTROL CENTER GRANT PROGRAM. Section 1273 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to maintain the Poison Control Center Grant Program. The Secretary will award grants to poison control centers and professional organizations for preventing poisonings, assisting in public health emergencies, and sustaining accreditation. Grants can also be used for research and evaluation purposes. The grants awarded under this program aim to research, establish, implement, and evaluate best practices for poisoning prevention, toxic exposure management, opioid misuse information, and public health emergency preparedness. Additionally, the grants support the improvement of national toxic exposure and opioid misuse surveillance through enhanced cooperation between poison control centers and governmental agencies. The program aims to enhance the poison control centers' communication and data system, support professional organizations in collecting national poisoning data, foster public health utilization of poison data, expand toxicologic expertise within centers. The program aims to improve poison control centers' capacity to handle high volumes of contacts and internet communications during national crises or public health emergencies. Accreditation by a nationally recognized professional organization or a State government is required to receive a grant from the Secretary. The Secretary may grant a waiver of accreditation requirements for a nonaccredited poison control center applying for a grant if they can demonstrate they will obtain accreditation within a reasonable period. The Poison Control Network Enhancement Act of 2018 limits waivers to poison control centers to a total of 5 years. Funding should supplement, not replace, other federal, state, or local funds. Centers must maintain their annual expenditures at 80% of the average level for the preceding 3 years. Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorization of appropriations totaling $28,600,000 for fiscal years 2019 through 2023 is provided for program administration functions under the Poison Control Network Enhancement Act of 2018. The Poison Control Network Enhancement Act of 2018 was passed by the House of Representatives on June 12, 2018. Karen L. Haas attested to the passing of the act.
